Title: Nanostructured porous manganese carbonate spheres with capacitive effects on the high lithium storage capability
Abstract: © 2015 The Royal Society of Chemistry.In this paper, nanostructured porous MnCO<inf>3</inf> spheres are facilely synthesized, which can simultaneously provide an increased surface for conversion reaction and capacitive storage as the anode material for lithium ion batteries. This material gives a superior specific capacity and excellent long-term cycling performance even at a high current density. It can deliver a stable capacity of 1049 mA h g<sup>-1</sup> after 200 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g<sup>-1</sup>, which is much higher than the theoretical capacity of 466 mA h g<sup>-1</sup>. After 2000 cycles at a high current density of 5000 mA g<sup>-1</sup>, a capacity of 510 mA h g<sup>-1</sup> can still be maintained. Their high rating performance at 5000 mA g<sup>-1</sup> is among the best-reported performances of anode materials. From the in situ or ex situ SEM observation, the porous MnCO<inf>3</inf> nanostructure can provide a stable template for reversible lithium insertion and extraction without significant morphology change and accommodate the volume change during the charge-discharge process. Also this structure increases the capacitive contribution to the total capacity compared with other MnCO<inf>3</inf> samples.
IndexKeywords: Anode material for lithium ion batteries
